metadata.title: Defective layered Mn-based cathode materials with excellent performance via ion exchange for Li-ion batteries

Red and yellow squares are used to mark reflection points at different locations and the corresponding inverse FFT with signal profiles of the selected red region. Fig. 5 (a) The initial charge/discharge cycling profiles and (b) corresponding differential capacity versus voltage (dQ/dV) curves (10 mA/g). (c) Long-term cycling stability at a rate of 40 mA/g and (d) rate performances from 0.1 to 2.0 C. Fig. 6 Normalized discharge profiles of (a) P600-LFMO, (b) P700-LFMO, and (c) P800-LFMO. The corresponding dQ/dV curves are shown in (d) P600-LFMO, (e) P700-LFMO, and (f) P800-LFMO, respectively. Fig. 7 (a) EIS spectra of PT-LFMO samples after the first activation and 30 cycles. GITT test voltage profiles and the corresponding Li+ diffusivity versus cell potential plots after the first activation (b, c) and 30th cycle (d, e). Precursor Chemical formula Target Chemical formula Naresidual Exchange degree NLFMO-600 Na0.83[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]O2 P600-LFMO Li0.58[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ 0.038 70.06% NLFMO-650 P650-LFMO Li0.59[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ 0.042 70.64% NLFMO-700 P700-LFMO Li0.78[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ 0.048 93.68% NLFMO-750 P750-LFMO Li0.69[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ 0.163 82.98% NLFMO-800 P800-LFMO Li0.65[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ 0.182 78.44% Defective layered Mn-based cathode materials with excellent performance via ion exchange for Li-ion batteries Yongheng Si Kun Bai Yaxin Wang Han Lu Litong Liu Ziyan Long Yujuan Zhao ⁎ Beijing Key Laboratory for Green Catalysis and Separation, Department of Chemistry, The Faculty of Environment and Life, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, China Beijing Key Laboratory for Green Catalysis and Separation Department of Chemistry The Faculty of Environment and Life Beijing University of Technology Beijing 100124 China Beijing Key Laboratory for Green Catalysis and Separation, Department of Chemistry, The Faculty of Environment and Life, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract O3-Li0.78[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ cathode made from P3 type precursor calcined at 700 °C through ion exchange method, the presence of a considerable number of defects results in an outstanding discharge capacity of 230 mAh/g with the initial coulombic efficiency about 109%. Defective layered Mn-based materials were synthesized by Li/Na ion exchange to improve their electrochemical activity and Coulombic efficiency. The annealing temperature of the Na precursors was important to control the P3-P2 phase transition, which directly affected the structure and electrochemical characteristics of the final products obtained by ion exchange. The O3-Li0.78[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ cathode made from a P3-type precursor calcined at 700 °C was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectrometry and electron paramagnetic resonance. The results showed that the presence of abundant trivalent manganese and defects resulted in a discharge capacity of 230 mAh/g with an initial Coulombic efficiency of about 109%. Afterward, galvanostatic intermittent titration was performed to examine the Li+ ion diffusion coefficients, which affected the reversible capacity. First principles calculations suggested that the charge redistribution induced by oxygen vacancies (OVs) greatly affected the local Mn coordination environment and enhanced the structural activity. Moreover, the Li-deficient cathode was a perfect match for the pre-lithiation anode, providing a novel approach to improve the initial Coulombic efficiency and activity of Mn-based materials in the commercial application. Keywords Ion exchange Defective cathode materials Oxygen vacancies Initial coulombic efficiency DFT calculations 1 Introduction Due to the rapid development of electric vehicles and the energy storage industry, there is an increasingly urgent need for advanced lithium-ion battery (LIB) systems [1]. Li-rich Mn-based (LRM) oxide electrodes have attracted attention because they can deliver a much higher energy density compared with traditional electrode materials such as LiCoO2 and LiFePO4 [2]. Looking back on a pivotal component Li2MnO3 is the main capacity contributor and is low-cost, rich in resources, and environmentally friendly. Unfortunately, it has inactive Mn4+ ions, and the activation process is kinetically unfavorable [3], which leads to a low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) and capacity decay during cycling process. The activation methods of Li2MnO3 mainly involve introducing structural defects such as lithium defects and oxygen vacancies (OVs) [4]. Lithium-deficient materials are mainly obtained by acid treatment and show high ICE values [5]. Strong acids such as H2SO4 [6] and HCl [7] are typically used to etch the surface, during which lithium ions are extracted through H+/Li+ exchange reactions. However, these chemicals may damage the original crystal structure of the material. Compared with lithium defects, OVs can alleviate the irreversibility of oxygen release and inhibit the phase transition from a layered to a spinel structure [8]. Major strategies either entail treating the materials under reductive atmospheres (such as CO [9] or Ar/H2 [10]) or reagents that can produce reducing gas (such as NH4HCO3 [11] and CO(NH2)2 [12]). Nevertheless, such severe experimental conditions are unsuitable for large-scale commercial production. During the synthesis of defective materials, ion exchange methods have received considerable attention and are considered to be directed topological reactions [13]. In detail, using sodium layered oxides (Na x TMO2, TM = Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, etc.) as precursors, lithium cathode materials with controllable structures were obtained by Li+/Na+ exchange in solution [14], organic solvents [15,16], or molten salts [17,18] containing Li+. These methods used a concentration difference and/or temperature as the driving force. Constructing a suitable structure of layered Na precursors is critical to ion exchange [19] because this process merely causes the transition metal (TM) layer to slip without breaking the TM–O bond, allowing it to inherit the structural properties of Na x TMO2 [20]. For example, Cao et al. [21] verified that the layered structure and inherent vacancies of Na2Mn3O7 were inherited by ion exchange, and a defective Li4/7[□1/7Mn6/7]O2 cathode material was obtained. Sun et al. [22] also used ion exchange to create Li2MnO3 cathode materials with structural defects, because the defects easily activated the Li2MnO3 phase and improved the electron and ion transport capabilities. Inspired by the above discussions, we introduced an ion exchange method to synthesize defective LRM cathode materials doped with trace amounts of Fe. This was performed because Fe doping may activate the redox activity of oxygen [23] and increase the discharge voltage [24]. Therefore, we designed Na precursors by regulating the calcination temperature and obtained the final products by ion exchange. Then, the basic structure and morphology were characterized by XRD and TEM. A considerable number of Mn3+ and OVs were detected according to EPR and XPS analysis. Furthermore, GITT and EIS were used to study the electrochemical kinetics. Based on the experimental results, we carried out simulations to elaborate on the structure–function relationship of this material with different OVs contents. These results may provide additional guidelines for the practical application of LRM cathodes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Na-based precursor Na0.83[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]O2 (NLFMO) precursors were prepared by a molten salt method. First, stoichiometric amounts (Na: Li: Fe: Mn = 0.830: 0.250: 0.075: 0.675) of Na(CH3COO)·3H2O, Li(CH3COO)·2H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, and Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O were weighed in a beaker and mixed evenly. Sodium salt and lithium salt were added in 5% excess to compensate for their loss during subsequent high-temperature calcination. Then, the beaker was heated in a water bath at 80 °C and mechanically stirred for about 1 h (the specific time was determined according to the humidity) until the mixture changed from liquid to black dry sand. The precursor mixture was heated in the air at 230 °C and then calcined for 10 h from 600 °C to 800 °C. The obtained sample was named NLFMO-T (where T indicates the calcination temperature). 2.2 Ion exchange process The NLFMO-T precursor and molten salt (lower-melting eutectic mixture [25] of 88 wt% LiNO3 and 12 wt% LiCl) of a seven-fold Li excess were thoroughly ground for 15 min. Then, the mixture was put into a furnace, and the reaction was performed at 280 °C in the air for 8 h to complete the Li+/Na+ exchange process. It was washed with deionized water and dried overnight at 80 °C. Finally, the final products PT-LFMO (T = 600 °C, 650 °C, 700 °C, 750 °C, and 800 °C) were obtained from their corresponding NLFMO-T precursor. Fig. 1 shows the schematic of ion exchange synthesis process of PT-LFMO materials. 2.3 Material characterization Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted on a Seiko Instruments 6300 TG-DTA by heating the NLFMO powder from 25 to 1000 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to characterize structural changes of the cathode materials by using Cu K α radiation in a 2θ range of 10°–80° and Rietveld refinement was performed using the FullProf Software package. The chemical composition changes caused by ion exchange were determined by Inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi) was conducted to analyze the valence states of surface elements. The micromorphologies of the samples were examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The in-depth lattice characteristics and element distribution were obtained by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL-JEM 2100) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, Oxford Instruments X-MaxN). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were acquired on a Bruker X-band A 200 computerized spectrometer in the X-band (9 GHz) at 100 kHz. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Cathodes were fabricated by casting the slurry mixing active materials (80 wt%), acetylene black (10 wt%), and poly(vinylidene fluoride) binder (10 wt%) on aluminum foil. Electrode discs (14 mm diameter) were punched from the electrode after being dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Li metal, glass fiber filter paper (Whatman), and 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in ethylene carbonate (EC)/dimethyl carbonate (DMC) mixture (1/1 v/v) served as the anode, separator, and electrolyte, respectively. Then, CR2032-type coin cells were assembled sequentially in an argon gas glovebox (H2O< 0.1 ppm and O2< 0.1 ppm). Galvanostatic charge/discharge cycle experiments were carried out on a NEWARE Battery Testing System with a potential range from 2–4.8 V at room temperature. The galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was performed at 0.1C with an interval of τ = 30 min after being activated. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS, VMP300) was performed at an amplitude of 5 mV and a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz. 2.5 Density functional theory calculations First-principles calculations were carried out by the density functional theory (DFT) approach using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). The exchange–correlation function was described using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). The strong correlation effect of the transition metal of 3d electron was taken into account using the GGA + U method with a Hubbard U value of 4.5 and 5.0 eV for Mn and Fe ions [26], respectively. The Monkhorst-Pack scheme (3 × 3 × 3 k-points mesh) was used for the integration in the irreducible Brillouin zone. The energy cutoff for the plane waves was 520 eV. The lattice parameters and ionic positions of the structure were fully relaxed, and the final forces on each relaxed atom were less than 0.01 eV/Å. The computational model was built based on the 2 × 1 × 2Li2MnO3 model (Li32Mn16O48), with 2 Fe atoms substituting 2Li atoms in the original model (Li30Fe2Mn16O48), and 1–4 oxygen atoms deducted in the defect model (Li30Fe2Mn16O47, Li30Fe2Mn16O46, Li30Fe2Mn16O45, Li30Fe2Mn16O44), respectively. The impact of Li defects was momentarily omitted during the calculating procedure to highlight the impact of oxygen vacancies. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and morphology characterization PT-LFMO was obtained through an ion exchange method from the NLFMO-T precursor (Fig. 1). TG analysis was used to choose the optimal calcination temperature for the precursor, as shown in Fig. S1. The first mass loss below 230 °C was mostly due to the removal of absorbed and crystalline water [27]. A sharp weight loss of 42% occurred between 230 and 360 °C, which was ascribed to the decomposition of acetate and nitrate in the precursor [28,29]. The third weight loss stage between 360 and 600 °C was probably the transition of oxide-crystal phases [30] accompanied by the release of gaseous byproducts such as CO2 [31]. The weight hardly changed above 600 °C. Hence, the calcination temperature was set from 600 °C. The chemical compositions of the materials were determined by ICP and the raw data are tabulated in Table S1. When normalized according to the Fe element, the calculated chemical formulas of the precursors are listed in Table 1 , which matched well with the initial designs. Most Na+ was replaced by Li+, and there was only a small amount of residue in the final products. Then, the degree of ion exchange changed according to the calcination temperatures of Na precursors (Table 1), and the highest degree of exchange reached 93.68% in the P700-LFMO sample. X-ray diffractograms were recorded for each precursor annealed at different temperatures (600, 650, 700, 750, and 800 °C), and the final products were obtained via ion exchange. In Fig. 2 (a), the diffraction peaks of NLFMO-600 and NLFMO-650 were similar to those of NLFMO-700. Whereas, the peak shapes of NLFMO-750 and NLFMO-800 were consistent with each other. Rietveld refinement showed that NLFMO-700 possessed a layered P3 structure with R3m space group symmetry [32] (Fig. 2b). The detailed crystallographic data, atomic coordinates, and occupancy parameters of this structure are listed in Table S2, which indicated a Li/Fe/Mn order in the TM layer. The diffraction peaks of NLFMO-800 were indexed to a typical P2-layered structure with the space group of P63/mmc [33] (Fig. S2). These results indicate that the NLFMO-T precursors underwent a P3-P2 phase transition as the calcination temperature increased. This was similar to the findings of Chagas [34], which showed that the calcination temperature directly affected the morphologies and phases of Na x Ni0.22Co0.11Mn0.66O2. Fig. 2(c) shows the XRD patterns of all PT-LFMO samples, which show that the P3-type precursors were converted to O3-type products. However, the peaks of P800-LFMO were different from those of a layered structure. This difference may be due to the air sensitivity of the P2-type NLFMO-800 precursor [35], which could have partially damaged its structure during the ion exchange process. Meanwhile, some diffraction peaks from Na x MnO2 impurity phases were detected. P700-LFMO has a perfect layered (α-NaFeO2 structure) O3-type arrangement (R-3 m space group) with ABCABC oxygen stacking along the c-axis (Fig. 2d and Table S3). The weak peaks between 20° and 25° belonged to the monoclinic structure (C2/m symmetry), reflecting the corresponding LiMn6 superlattice arrangement of the LRM cathodes [36]. Fig. 2(e) shows the changes in crystal structure after ion exchange. The (003) diffraction peak in P700-LFMO shifted to a higher angle at 18.7° (Fig. 2e, inset), suggesting the shrinking of interlayer spacing along the c-axis due to a change in the coordination environment from prismatic to octahedral in alkali metal slabs. Further, the P700-LFMO diffraction peak intensity decreased and broadened, indicating imperfection of crystallinity [6]. Based on the detailed analysis, the mechanism for the ion exchange route is proposed in Fig. 2(f). Precisely, the transformation is only from sodium-prismatic to lithium-octahedron (from P-O phase transition). The anion sublattice of the precursor was well preserved after ion exchange, allowing for the formation of highly-crystalline layered oxides. The morphologies of the various NLFMO-T and PT-LFMO samples were examined by SEM. Fig. S3(a–c) shows that the particle size of the NLFMO-T precursors increased with the calcination temperature. Agglomeration was more serious for the NLFMO-600 precursor owing to the greater surface energy of smaller particles [37], which may have impeded the extent of ion exchange. Nevertheless, after ion exchange, the aggregates were dispersed into uniform particles (Fig. S3 a'–c'). EDX analysis showed the presence of more residual Na in P800-LFMO (Fig. S3a″–c″) because crystal growth at 800 °C created longer ion exchange paths. The internal structure of the NLFMO-700 precursor and P700-LFMO sample was further investigated via HRTEM. Fig. 3(a and b) compare the precursor and final product, which shows that P700-LFMO was composed of nanoparticles with an average size of about 100–200 nm and a more homogeneous particle size distribution (Fig. S4). Fig. 3(c) reveals the clear straight crystal lattice of the P700-LFMO sample, and their inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) patterns (red square, Fig. 3c) showed a lattice fringe layer spacing of 0.472 nm, which was indexed to the (003) and/or (001) plane of orderly layered phase [38]. The corresponding inverse Fourier transform signal (yellow square, Fig. 3c) in the interior of the particle showed a few stacking fault defects, attributed to the asymmetric ion radii during ion exchange [39]. TEM-EDS (Fig. 3d and e) shows that Na, Fe, and Mn elements were uniformly distributed throughout the particles, and there was little Na element in the P700-LFMO product after ion exchange. This shows that the desired product with a well-layered structure was successfully synthesized via the ion exchange route. The XPS spectra are displayed in Fig. S5, from which Na, Fe, Mn, and O were detected on the surface of the final products. The O 1s XPS spectra in Fig. 4 (a) display three distinct characteristic peaks around 529.2, 531.4, and 532.1 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (M−O), oxygen vacancies, and carbonate species [40], respectively. The area ratios of the peaks representing oxygen vacancies of P600-LFMO, P700-LFMO, and P800-LFMO were 11.88%, 22.61%, and 7.87%, respectively. In addition, the EPR spectrum in Fig. 4(b) presents a signal at a g-factor of 2.003, indicating the presence of OVs in PT-LFMO samples [41]. P700-LFMO showed the strongest EPR signal, followed by P600-LFMO, and P800-LFMO was the lowest. Thus, the XPS and EPR results show that the order of the OVs concentration was P700-LFMO > P600-LFMO > P800-LFMO. In layered full-Mn cathode materials, considering charge balance [42], the absence of oxygen resulted in a reduction of Mn4+. As shown in Fig. 4(c), analyzing the Mn peaks [43] showed that the peak located at 642.8 eV in the Mn 2p 3/2 spectrum was assigned to Mn4+, while the peak at 641.9 eV was assigned to Mn3+. The Mn4+ state was dominant in all PT-LFMO samples, but the Mn3+ peak intensity was slightly higher in the P700-LFMO sample compared with the others. This indicates that the number of electrochemically-active Mn3+ increased upon increasing the number of oxygen vacancies [40,44]. Generally, Mn3+ could contribute capacity due to its electrochemically active characteristic, but the content of Mn3+ in P800-LFMO was almost negligible, and Mn4+ occupied almost 90% of the sample, indicating that the structure was relatively stable. From the Fe 2p spectra in Fig. 4(d), the two peaks [45] at 711.16 and 724.60 eV corresponding to Fe 2p 1/2 and Fe 2p 3/2 were indexed to Fe3+, and there were no obvious changes in the position of the main peaks. 3.2 Electrochemical properties of the PT-LFMO based electrodes The electrochemical properties of PT-LFMO based electrodes were systemically tested in half-cells between 2.0 and 4.8 V vs. Li+/Li. Fig. 5 (a) is the initial charge/discharge curves at a 0.2C rate. There was a stable voltage plateau at about 4.5 V for all samples, which is a typical characteristic of anion redox reactions in Li-rich materials. The P700-LFMO sample had high initial charge/discharge capacities of about 210/230 mAh/g. Fig. S6 displays the initial and cyclic performance profiles at five different calcination temperatures of the obtained PT-LFMO products. The detailed charge/discharge specific capacities and ICE data are summarized in Table S4. It is evident that the ICE of all products was greater than 100% because the Li-deficient product could accommodate more Li ions during discharging [46]. The initial charge/discharge cycle of the LRM materials, referred to as an activation cycle, gives clear insight into the charge compensation mechanism. Fig. 5(b) illustrates the dQ/dV plots corresponding to the charge/discharge profiles at a current density of 10 mA/g. The anodic peak at ≈3.0 V was attributed to the Mn3+/Mn4+ in P600-LFMO and P700-LFMO, which indicates better activation of the Li2MnO3 component [47]. This is in good agreement with the XPS analysis. Moreover, during charging, a small plateau at 3.0 V verified the above results (Fig. S7). Then, activated Mn4+ was reduced, as shown by the peak near 2.6 V. A distinct oxidation peak above 4.5 V indicates the involvement of anions in the oxidation reaction. Then, the oxidation peak of P700-LFMO was lower than that of P600-LFMO, which corresponds to its short platform charging capacity. This phenomenon shows that more OVs reduced the oxygen partial pressure on the surface of P700-LFMO and inhibited the oxidation of irreversible oxygen during high-voltage charging [11,48]. The cycling capacity and rate performance at high rates were also tested to determine the activation degree. Fig. 5(c) shows that P700-LFMO delivered the highest capacity of 173 mAh/g after 50 cycles with a capacity retention of 75%, compared with 145 mAh/g for P600-LFMO and 123 mAh/g for P800-LFMO. As shown in Fig. 5(d), P700-LFMO delivered discharge capacities of 255, 224, 177, 129, and 76 mAh/g at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 C, respectively. The high specific discharge capacity at different rates was due to the presence of OVs, which provided sufficient channels for the diffusion of Li+ ions and electron transport [42]. When the current density was returned to 0.1 C, P700-LFMO quickly retained a reversible capacity of 221 mAh/g, which was much higher than that of P600-LFMO and P800-LFMO under the same conditions. P700-LFMO also showed good stability at 1.0 C, with a reversible discharge capacity of 110.30 mAh/g after 100cycles (Fig. S8). P800-LFMO showed the worst performance due to the insufficient released electrochemical activity from the Li2MnO3 component [3,49]. Then, Fig. S9(a) shows the first cycle charge–discharge curves of P700-LMO without Fe doping and P700-LFMO under the same experimental conditions. P700-LFMO had a higher discharge voltage. In addition, for a better comparison among the materials, the average discharge voltage obtained from the potential profiles is depicted in Fig. S9(b). After 50cycles, the average discharge voltage of P700-LFMO decreased from 3.23 to 2.99 V (ΔE = 0.24 V), while the voltage decay for the P700-LMO sample was 0.28 V. This phenomenon was more obvious in P650-LFMO and P650-LMO samples (Fig. S9c, d). Therefore, doping with Fe significantly enhanced the discharge voltage and voltage decay of PT-LFMO, which is consistent with previous research [50,51]. Overall, P700-LFMO exhibited the best electrochemical characteristics, and the comparison in Table S5 underlines the good performance of the cell created herein compared with other reported Co/Ni-free cells. The effect of OVs on voltage decay and polarization was investigated by analyzing normalized discharge curves (Fig. 6 a–c) and dQ/dV curves (Fig. 6d–f). The P600-LFMO and P700-LFMO samples exhibited voltage decay only in the middle and low-voltage regions (2.4–3.4 V) and remained stable at discharge voltages above 3.6–4.8 V (Fig. 6a and b). The voltage decay curve of P700-LFMO had a higher degree of coincidence. In contrast, the discharge voltage of the P800-LFMO sample decreased over the entire voltage range, likely due to its imperfect crystal structure (Fig. 6c). As previously reported [52,53], the introduction of OVs can alleviate voltage decay during cycling by enhancing the reversibility of TM migration, thereby improving the capacity retention. In Fig. 6(e), the P700-LFMO had the highest intensity peak of Mn3+/Mn4+ and a small change in redox potential (0.18 V), which is consistent with its electrochemical cycling stability and high OVs content. Additionally, it exhibited the smallest potential intervals of cathodic/anodic peaks (0.14 V), suggesting reduced polarization and enhanced Li+ diffusion kinetics [41]. The EIS spectra and GITT measurements of PT-LFMO products after activation and after 30 cycles were performed at 0.1 C to analyze the electrochemical kinetics. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), the impedance spectra contained a semicircle due to charge transfer (R ct) in the high-frequency region. The diagonal line indicated the Warburg impedance (W o). After activation, P600-LFMO exhibited the lowest R ct impedance, which corresponded to a high specific capacity during the first cycle. However, the R ct impedance of the P700-LFMO sample after 30 cycles was lower than that of the other two samples, showing that it has better reaction kinetics. The GITT curves of different samples during charging and discharging are plotted in Fig. 7(b and d). After activation, the polarization of P600-LFMO was the weakest when the voltage was below 4.2 V (Fig. 7b). Upon extending the number of cycles in Fig. 7(d), the polarization of P700-LFMO was significantly reduced, which was also consistent with the results obtained by fitting the impedance spectra. Additionally, the lithium-ion diffusion rate at different states was calculated from the GITT data (see the detailed calculation process in the Supporting Information). Compared with P600-LFMO and P800-LFMO samples, the average Li+ diffusion coefficient of P700-LFMO was much higher during prolonged cycling (Table S6), which explains why its rate capacity was better [54]. Fig. 7(c and e) show that D Li+ was higher at 3.0–4.2 V for P600-LFMO and P700-LFMO samples, indicating that the cationic electrochemical reaction kinetics were fast and were an important contributor to the capacity [55]. Comprehensive analysis showed that P700-LFMO had faster lithium ion diffusion and exhibited enhanced electrochemical kinetics and cycling performance. 3.3 Mechanisms based on first-principles calculations (DFT) To further understand the effect of OVs in PT-LFMO samples, first-principles calculations were conducted based on the DFT method. Fig. 8 (a–d) show the pristine LFMO model and defective models with different OVs ratios. We calculated the projected density of states (PDOS) of the electronic structure for each model (Fig. 8a'd'). The results show that the density of states near the valence band is mainly composed of O-2p states and Mn-3d states, while the density of states near the conduction band is mainly composed of O-2p states, Mn-3d states, and Fe-3d states. Compared to the sample without OVs (Fig. 8a'), the defective model with OVs had some obvious electron density of TM-3d and O-2p in the vicinity of the Femi energy (Fig. 8b') [49]. In addition, upon increasing the OVs content, the band gap between the valence band and the conduction band narrowed (Fig. 8d'), thereby improving the overall electronic conductivity [56]. This corresponded to the larger diffusion ability of lithium ions in the P700-LFMO sample. For each model, structural optimization was carried out while maintaining the same cell characteristics [50]. Then, the differential charge density was calculated to further study the effect of OVs on the electronic states of the entire system. Decreasing and increasing charge density was represented by cyan and yellow regions, respectively (Fig. S11). According to the planar differential charge (Fig. 8e–g), as the OVs content increased, there were more delocalized electrons around the TM, which resulted in higher activity [57]. Bader charge analysis showed that the formation of oxygen vacancies mainly caused charge redistribution of the nearest Mn atoms (Fig. S12, Tables S7 and S8). This corresponded to Mn3+ in the XPS results. Furthermore, the presence of many free electrons could potentially enhance the structural distortion of the MnO6 octahedron, thereby facilitating the activation of certain Mn ions [40,58]. Therefore, effectively utilizing the redox capability of Mn can provide more capacity during charge and discharge processes. 4 Conclusions Here, a series of defective Li x [Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ cathode materials were created via an ion exchange method using P-type Na precursors synthesized via calcination from 600 to 800 °C. The XRD results of the Na precursors suggested that they had either a P3-type (700 °C) or a P2-type structure (800 °C). Especially, O3-type Li0.78[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ (P700-LFMO) with a well-crystallized layered structure was produced from the P3-type precursor. P700-LFMO showed the most Mn3+ and OVs, followed by P600-LFMO and P800-LFMO, which displayed a relatively high initial Coulombic efficiency exceeding 100% and electrochemical activity. Combined with electrochemical performance and kinetic properties analysis, the P700-LFMO sample presented a superior Li-ion diffusion capacity and distinctly relieved polarization. Theoretical calculations consistently showed that OVs affected the electronic structure of local Mn atoms, and a reduced band gap increased the electrical conductivity. These findings may provide novel guidance for developing high-performance, low-cost Li-rich Mn-based cathodes for next-generation Li-ion batteries. coredata.dc:description: Defective layered Mn-based materials were synthesized by Li/Na ion exchange to improve their electrochemical activity and Coulombic efficiency. The annealing temperature of the Na precursors was important to control the P3-P2 phase transition, which directly affected the structure and electrochemical characteristics of the final products obtained by ion exchange. The O3-Li0.78[Li0.25Fe0.075Mn0.675]Oδ cathode made from a P3-type precursor calcined at 700 °C was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectrometry and electron paramagnetic resonance. The results showed that the presence of abundant trivalent manganese and defects resulted in a discharge capacity of 230 mAh/g with an initial Coulombic efficiency of about 109%. Afterward, galvanostatic intermittent titration was performed to examine the Li+ ion diffusion coefficients, which affected the reversible capacity. First principles calculations suggested that the charge redistribution induced by oxygen vacancies (OVs) greatly affected the local Mn coordination environment and enhanced the structural activity. Moreover, the Li-deficient cathode was a perfect match for the pre-lithiation anode, providing a novel approach to improve the initial Coulombic efficiency and activity of Mn-based materials in the commercial application.

coredata.dc:title: Defective layered Mn-based cathode materials with excellent performance via ion exchange for Li-ion batteries
